title: 108_hr3796
content: The Act may be cited as the "Abandoned Mine Lands Reclamation Reform Act of 2004" and includes amendments to the Surface Mining Act. Amendments to Section 401 of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 involve redesignating paragraphs and adjusting sentences for achieving the purposes of transfers under section 402(h). Additionally, Section 712(b) is amended by changing a reference from section 401(c)(11) to section 401(c)(9). Amendments to Section 402 of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 include changes such as reducing numbers and adjusting figures. Subsection (g)(1)(D) is modified to specify grants under paragraph (5). The Secretary must ensure strict compliance with priorities in section 403(a) until certification is made under section 411(a). Subsection (g)(3) is amended to adjust figures and specify grants under paragraph (5). Subsection (g)(5) is also amended to increase funds from 40 to 60. The Secretary must ensure compliance with priorities in section 403(a) until certification under section 411(a). Subsection (g)(3) adjusts figures and specifies grants under paragraph (5), while subsection (g)(5) increases funds from 40 to 60. Subsection (g)(6) allows States with approved mine reclamation programs to retain up to 10% of grants annually without a 3-year limitation. The curr_chunk discusses the establishment of an acid mine drainage abatement and treatment fund under State law to address the effects of acid mine drainage in hydrologic units affected by coal mining practices. The term "qualified hydrologic unit" is defined as a unit impacted by acid mine drainage that adversely affects biological resources and meets certain criteria outlined in the paragraph. The curr_chunk amends subsection (g)(7) to allow States or Indian tribes to use grants for reclamation of eligible lands and waters affected by acid mine drainage before completing other reclamation projects. The curr_chunk amends subsection (g)(8) to ensure that grants for reclamation projects are allocated to each State and Indian tribe, with a minimum of $2,000,000 annually per recipient. Additionally, subsection (h) is amended to specify the transfer of interest earnings to the Combined Fund. The curr_chunk amends Section 403 of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 by making various changes to paragraphs (1), (2), and (3). The curr_chunk further amends Section 406 of the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 by making changes to subsections (d) and (e), including updating references and authorizing appropriations to the Secretary. The Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 is amended to authorize appropriations to the Secretary of Agriculture and make changes to Sections 408 and 411, allowing the Secretary to make certifications on behalf of States or Indian tribes for reclamation projects. The Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 is amended to authorize appropriations to the Secretary of Agriculture and make changes to Sections 408 and 411, allowing the Secretary to make certifications on behalf of States or Indian tribes for reclamation projects. The Secretary shall certify completion of reclamation projects for eligible lands and water in a State or tribe after public notice and comment. Additionally, qualified States will receive a proportional share of funds from the Mineral Leasing Act for reclamation projects. The Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 authorizes appropriations to the Secretary of Agriculture and allows for certifications on behalf of States or Indian tribes for reclamation projects. Qualified States will receive funds from the Mineral Leasing Act for reclamation projects. Payments to States under this subsection will be made in the same manner as payments under the Mineral Leasing Act. Amendment to the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 changes the year from "2004" to "2019" in Section 510(e) (30 U.S.C. 1260(e)). PROVISIONS RELATING TO THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THIS TITLE. The Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977 allows for the allocation of amounts for program transfers in fiscal year 2004 and beyond. Interest credited to the fund established by the Act can be transferred to the Combined Benefit Fund. The Secretary of the Interior will review additions to the inventory to ensure they reflect eligible lands and waters meeting specified priorities under the Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977.
